ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: A more detailed and fundamental understanding of chemical mechanisms, principles, and syntheses.
I increased my knowledge of chemical systems and strengthened my understanding of carbonyl-based mechanisms.
Alkyne rxns, Diels Alder, carbonyl chemistry

This class actually teaches you how to THINK about organic chemistry!! Unlike other memorization-heavy chemistry courses, this course is focused on teaching us major chemistry concepts and allowing us to apply these concepts. I feel like I've walked away from the course knowing so much more about fundamental organic chemistry, and ways to apply these principles through synthesis/mechanisms/etc.
So many reaction mechanisms--and also their patterns that make them similar. Being able to draw out arrow pushing mechanisms for mechanisms and propose reagent pathways for retrosynthesis.

We went through Diels-Alder, carbonyl chemistry, enolates, amines, and many many other chemical reactions. We learned how to do retrosynthesis efficiently, and also the underlying concepts behind the reactions, such as structure-reactivity trends, acidity and how it all relates to bio in some way.

Built well off of what I learned in Orgo I. Biggest thing I took out of it was developing a better intuition with orgo that I didn't really have down-pat from 174. In Orgo II I learned about the Diels-Alder reaction, alkynes, a lot about carbonyls, enolate chemistry, and the nitro group (which was an extra topic this year because we had time leftover).
Organic chemistry II concepts
I learned about more complex organic chemical reactions, such as with alkynes, aromatic compounds, and carbonyls. I learned how to reason through complex mechanisms and synthetic rout propositions.
I learned a huge amount of chemical reactions, and gained a better intuition for synthesis routes and reaction mechanisms in organic chemistry.
I definitely learned a lot of ochem through this course. I feel like I strengthened my problem solving skills through the types of questions given on psets and exams.
I learned a lot about carbonyl chemistry and some very fancy, complicated, chemical reactions.
Cemented organic chemistry knowledge

I learned about reactions with aromatic systems, carbonyl reactions, aldol reactions, and reactions with amines. I also learned how to think critically about a reaction to understand the molecular behavior that goes into the mechanism behind that reaction and how to approach problems that I may not have seen before in organic chemistry.
Expansion of organic chemistry knowledge from CHEM 175. We learned many different chemical reactions grouped in categories: carbonyls, enolates, carboxylic acids, amines, etc
I learned about many types of organic chem reactions, including alkyne and Diels-Alder reactions, various oxidations and reductions, and carbonyl and enolate reactions.
Problem solving.

I learned about organic chemistry topics ranging from Diels-Alder, alkynes, and carbonyl chemistry. Additionally, the course improved my ability to problem-solve and learn from my mistakes in high-pressure situations. I gained a familiarity of dealing with mechanisms and retrosynthesis problems.
I learned a lot of synthetic techniques and reactions that can be used. I also trained my chemical intuition with the wide variety of reactions.
A broad overview of aromatic, carbonyl and nitrogen chemistry  all incredibly interesting topics.
reactions with ketones, amines, amides, and Diels Alder and more general retrosynthesis and mechanism work
More about organic chemistry, specifically with a focus on mechanisms and synthesis reactions mostly based around carbonyls.
Lots of mechanisms and reactions that allowed me to more deeply understand the logic behind semester 1 material

How and why some organic molecules react the way they do with a focus on alkynes , carbonyls, carboxylic acids and their derivatives. 

Learned some problem solving techniques and thinking strategies by means of organic synthesis and mechanism problems, which taught how to apply ideas  already known to unfamiliar but related problems.
I learned more reactions and new mechanisms and how to apply them to synthesis problems.

We learned about many interesting organic chemistry reactions with alkynes, aromatics, aldehydes, carboxylic acids, ketones, enolates, and amines. This is also a great course to practice problem solving + coming up with creative ways to synthesize molecules.
I learned a lot about organic reactions and how to predict how molecules interact, as well as how these reactions can be useful in the real world.
Better intuitive understanding of chemical behavior/reactivity; Diels-Alder, carbonyl, enolate, amine reactions. Retrosynthesis analysis and mechanism proposal.
Methods for synthesis's and mechanisms.

I learned a lot of different organic chemistry reactions relating to alkynes, nitriles, carbonyls, carboxylic acids, nitro groups, and amine groups. Then there were some conceptual ideas related to these reactions like the particular bond angles, MO theory, hyperconjugation, pka of acids and bases, regiochemistry, and stereochemistry when applicable.
I developed an insight into synthesizing organic molecules, and developed a good understanding of reagents.
knowledge of aromatic systems, reaction mechanisms, aldol and enolate chemistry; retrosynthetic analysis, analysis of mechanisms, justification of ideas using molecular orbital theory.
I gained alot of insight into how to make the most efficient synthesis available and also learned alot about the history behind reactions.
I learned various organic chemistry reactions, how to solve retrosynthetic problems, and use prior knowledge to suggest plausible mechanisms to reaction schemes.
LOTS of organic chemistry! Alkynes, the Diels-Alder Reaction, carbonyls, carboxylic acids, amines, and more
Alkyne, aromatic and carbonyl chemistry, several reactions and mechanisms, and retrosynthetic analysis
Organic chemistry synthesis procedures.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The course time was way too early for students in different time zones. 75 minutes of lecture at 6 or 7 am twice a week, every single week, is brutal.
I believe that changing the style of PSets to a less stress-inducing and learning-focused format would improve the experience.

I swear, there was zero communication between the professor and the TAs/peer tutors. There were so many problems assigned in the PSET that were not covered until later in class (e.g., Baeyer-Villiger, Wittig reaction, malonic ester synthesis). Test content was fair and I appreciated having 75 minutes rather than the 50 minutes that wed get in 174, though Im pretty sure there were several people who cheated on them this year because they were held over Zoom, so fair can only go so far. This class is curved up to a B+/A- average, so I guess thats not terrible if youre doing average in the class. There was only one TA that gave practice problems reflective of the exam, and there was one TA who grade significantly harsher than the others, but thats probably not going to be applicable in future years.

Strengths: THE PROFESSOR!! In terms of organic chem, Prof Spiegel is the best professor you could ask for. The class is perfectly-paced, and he is very thorough and clear in his lectures. This class is not a memorization class - you actually LEARN about organic chemistry. Prof Spiegel is also very welcoming and open to questions. He makes time to chat with students and holds review sessions before every exam. Beyond teaching, he is also a terrific human. He is so relatable, funny, and approachable. It makes for the perfect class. 
Weakness: NONE
There was some miscommunication between TAs and the professor that made some logistical things confusing, and sections between TAs were very different. TAs and peer tutors were a great help.

Strengths: TAs really carried, and the weakly discussion sections really helped to solidify the material covered in class. Also the extra sessions that some of the TAs conducted helped a lot in exam preparation.

Weaknesses: The practice exams sometimes did not match the actual exams, which was only concerning for the final exam. At times I felt lost as to why we were covering a certain subject, and for the greater half of the semester we didn't follow what was on the syllabus. The pacing at times was also kind of slow, especially in the beginning of the semester.

Strengths: A lot of opportunities for learning and studying, good support network (peer tutors were always there to help). TFs were very dedicated and helpful.
Weaknesses: It felt like there was a little lack of communication or organization between the professor and the TFs.

The online lectures were chaotic and the professor was often not prepared/showed up late. He explained reaction mechanisms well, but the PSETs and exams were incredibly difficult and the material covered in lectures was not enough. We rarely received guidance on how to study for this course and it was hard to get a sense of how prepared we were before exams.

I learned the most through the office hours held weekly with peer tutors. They really did a lovely job breaking down course material into more simple, easy-to-understand terms. I also thought the course was well-organized, and I thought that the problem sets allowed me to grasp material a bit better. I thought exams were significantly more difficult than problem sets, examples in class, and practice problems. I personally believe that neither the totally flipped classroom approach nor a standard lecture is the best format of the class, but rather a mix, explaining concepts and then providing more examples of each reaction. Lectures often went into tangents, which were sometimes interesting, but not always very relevant and often just made the concepts more confusing for me. I really think focusing on explaining the concepts and providing a couple examples, especially for more complex/difficult reactions would be helpful. Often I found myself making mistakes in assignments because I did not fully understand the rules or conditions of reactions.  Additionally, I think that the discussion sections could be redundant at times, and it would be nice to see the sections catered a bit more towards students' needs -- addressing common pitfalls, practicing with examples similar to those on assignments, and really explaining the "why" behind some of the key reactions.

A major weakness of the course is that students are expected to intuit whether or not a certain reaction or mechanistic step will take place, even when no analogous processes have been presented in class. Worse, much of organic chemistry is educated guesswork, and it's extremely frustrating as a student when the TAs, professor, and peer tutors all disagree about the answer to a practice problem and none of them can definitively prove the others wrong. That being said, I did get better over the course of the semester at making these educated guesses, but I wish this had been through specific explanations rather than a gradual process of pattern-recognition on what types of answers tended to be correct.

Sometimes, I felt as if the exam content was disconnected from psets and what was being taught in lecture. Specifically, exam 2 contained a lot of mechanism questions but we had not done much practice with that prior to the exam. It was only after exam 2 where we had extensive practice with mechanisms on the problem sets. 

Overall, it was a well-taught course and I could tell that the professor cared about our learning and well-being.

The lecture format was not very engaging over Zoom, but Professor Spiegel tried to make it more interesting with breaks which was nice. There was a lot of support in terms of peer tutor study halls and discussion sections, which was very helpful.
Much of the weakness came from the virtual aspect of the learning environment.

Strengths: There is no homework other than 6 psets throughout the semester, so the relative day-to-day workload is pretty small if there isn't an exam coming up. The lecturer also tries to be engaging with the students and includes a break in the middle of the lecture to lighten the mood.

Weaknesses: This isn't necessarily a weakness persay, but the exams and problem sets will challenge you, ESPECIALLY the exams since they are under time pressure and you can't simply go to office hours during an exam to get help on how to solve a problem (you can do that for psets, but obviously not during an exam). Some questions on the exam will feel impossible and sometimes the molecular behavior in the mechanism will also look unfamiliar, which may throw you off during that exam. In fact, for this semester, in my experience, the exams always had at least one question like this, where one has to really think in order to solve the question. Suffice it to say, the exams are hard and you may do worse than you had hoped coming into the exam - the answers aren't always straightforward and you will be challenged. Some of the TAs also grade harshly on the exams, which has definitely happened to me at least twice this semester, so beware. However, the exams are curved though and you do get one exam drop, which is useful to know if you happen to receive a particularly bad grade.
Personally, I stressed a lot whenever an exam came up because of the difficulty level of the exams, if the difficulty level for these exams could be lowered, that would be nice for future students.

Strengths: TAs were very helpful and there were lots of opportunities to get help. 
Weaknesses: Lots of miscommunications between the professor, TAs, and peer tutors on solutions to practice problems as well as what to know for the exams. Large lecture with no group work wasn't great for engagement. Very hard to gauge the level of difficulty of the exams because it wasn't usually like the practice exams or the psets so it felt like we were going in blind sometimes.

Strengths: nice, funny professor; TAs are good at explaining material; professor did study sessions before tests; peer tutors were helpful 
Weaknesses: there are a few weaknesses to this course. For one, the tests often were often more complicated than the material we covered in lecture. In lecture, we only covered the basic reactions, while the tests sometimes had mechanisms that we had never heard of in lecture. The TAs sometimes covered this extra material in the discussion section, but I would have appreciated practicing coming up with new mechanisms in lecture, which often was chalked up to having "chemical intuition." Second, I thought there was somewhat of a disconnect between what the professor was saying in lecture and what the TAs were doing in section, which could sometimes be seen in the grading or writing of assignments, especially the final exam, which was described very differently and ended up being quite confusing. Third, in the grading sometimes I had questions about what I could have done better, but I sometimes did not receive a clear response from the TA in charge of that question, or even a response at all.
The class was very disorganized and unnecessarily stressful. Professor Spiegel, the TAs, and the peer tutors often explained concepts in a contradictory manner.
Better Organization

A more clear curriculum would be appreciated. I felt that especially toward the last part of the course, most of lecture was just bringing up random reactions and not really exploring the in-depth rationale behind the proposed mechanisms.

This course was very informative and I learned a lot. However, at certain moments, it felt as if we were just going through a list of reactions and engagement dipped at these moments. It is also certainly a lot to learn, but not unmanageable by any means.

Orgo 2 was the most intellectually course I took in my first year but I absolutely loved it. The lectures were easy to follow but the exams were much harder and more complex than any of the seemingly facile problems we discussed in class. As a result, there was a lot of self-learning from textbook, the internet and study groups that was necessary to do well. However, this form of active learning was very rewarding personally  that might not be the case for everyone.
I enjoyed the interactivity of the class and the applications of what we were learning that were discussed during class

Overall, organic chemistry is a difficult course in general. Lecture was really more of a way for Prof Spiegel to let us know what we needed to learn and teach ourselves after class. However, given the sheer volume of reactions we need to learn over the semester, this really might be the only way to teach, even if it wouldve been nice to have time to digest material during class rather than scribbling down things to learn later.
Grading felt harsh at times and there was a disconnect between the Professor and the TAs when it came to the administrative portions of the class (grading etc, test topics etc.)

Strengths: peer tutor hours were helpful and the material was interesting if you understood it. 
Weaknesses: the professors and TAs were not super responsive when reaching out for additional help or resources. The professor had a tendency to ramble during lecture and often was unaware what would be covered on the exams. Remedying the reactions covered in the book with what was in section and lecture was often difficult.

Strengths - The problem sets were good, and the TFs and TAs were very helpful. Prof. Spiegel was engaging during lecture despite the Zoom format. 
Weaknesses - Sometimes the slides would be difficult to find after lecture.
This course covered a lot of material quickly and effectively but did not do much to make sure that different material was connected and everyone was on the same page.

Strengths: For what organic chemistry seems to be about, Spiegel does a decent job of teaching it. He has a practical understanding of how reactions work and knows their real-life applications, which were helpful and interesting to know (I found them useful but some people thought of these as random tangents). Problem sets were both fair in difficulty and length; so were exams. In general, the class does not feel too overwhelming. Also, a lot of help is available through peer tutors, section, review sessions, etc. 
Weaknesses: While I thought Spiegel did a decent job, he was very disorganized and seemed to put little effort in lectures. I think he pretty much always taught lectures from his bed, and many times it seemed like he woke up right before class. Often he would go over mechanisms for reactions without explaining fully the driving forces behind it, specific details, etc. Also, we were never taught some material (such as protecting groups), but at some point we were just expected to know it. But overall, the weaknesses are not overwhelming, I learned a lot about orgo, and the class is pretty reasonable.
Helpful professor and TAs but more test level practice questions would have been helpful.

The strengths of this course mainly lies in the clear expectations of what we are expected to know through practice exams and the discussion sections for the most of the course. However, the course had many weaknesses. I think the lectures were too general as in the specific ways to utilize the concepts were not discussed enough because when the exams and psets came, I felt not prepared enough to use the knowledge we learned in the lectures to answer the questions. More examples would've been helpful. The lectures are mainly made up of reactions and mechanisms that were simply given to us in a way that made memorizing them the main way to study. I ended up thinking that memorizing all the reactions we learned in class was a foundational step in order to do the higher level thinking that would enable me to answer the exam questions. Thus, I would have preferred an underlying mechanism or concept behind all the information given in class mentioned in the lecture to help remembering the material in a useful way.

This course provides a good introduction to organic chemistry. However, the lectures were a little unrelated to the actual exams often, and the relevance of the lectures to the tested content could be improved.

This course is awesome, you learn so much. The only thing that can be improved is not to backload so much. There were so many reactions that were thrown at us that we could not possibly in a short stretch. Hurry over alkenes and Diels-Alder which we already learned most of and then take time on examples of the named reactions later, especially seeing additions/condensations in synthesis problems. David Spiegel is awesome

Strengths: material is well taught with applications in the medical and biological sciences; helpful anecdotes are provided such that there is clear use of the material in real world applications. Professor Spiegel taught the material very clearly and effectively. 

Weaknesses: there needed to be a more equitable grading system, such that smaller or trivial errors took off 1/4-1/2 the points of the question. Exam rubrics should be based on knowledge of the material rather than the ability to copy down structures exactly correctly between steps. There needs to be set proctoring from the first exam onwards, in breakout rooms, as other classes have done in during this past semester, and every student should be required to sign an honor pledge on each individual exam.
One big strength was the fact that the course really encouraged asking questions. One weakness was there wasn't alot of cohesiveness between the TA's.
Strengths: the discussion sections were very helpful for clarifying concepts; Weaknesses: exam questions were often very hard and the grading was not particularly forgiving if a mistake was made

Discussion section was extremely useful. However, problem sets should have been graded prior to exams (with time to spare); having no sense of whether you were doing problems correctly made it extremely difficult to prepare for exams. Answer keys should also have been released for problem sets and exams; it's hard to learn when you're told what you did wrong but still don't grasp how to do it right.
The course was very in-depth, but problem sets did not correlate well with the exams.
The lectures were not conducive to explaining course material on PSETS or exams.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I believe that the recorded lectures made this course accessible for students across the world, which was good. Overall, the course was well adapted to the situation.
Recorded lectures were helpful.

I really liked the review sessions before exams, and the Zoom breaks during lecture were much-needed and helped create a lovely sense of community. Professor Spiegel was very personable and engaging throughout the semester -- I wouldn't change a thing.
Having weekly office hours in addition to section is very helpful.

Succeeded: Online lectures and online practice materials were helpful.

Improved: Better test taking procedures online. The practice problems and slides were also a bit disorganized in the Canvas space.
The hand-drawn powerpoint lectures were far less than ideal. There was also no interactive component in lectures. CHEM 174 with Timothy Newhouse was formatted a lot better for online learning.

Personally, I think that the lectures could have been more engaging. I think it would have potentially been helpful to have breakout rooms to work practice questions or think about examples of the reactions. I also think, and this is not necessarily the fault of Professor Spiegel, that the notes written on PowerPoint slides were not always very clear and well-organized, making it difficult to decipher when moving as quickly as this class does. I do think Professor Spiegel did a nice job trying to foster a community in this virtual format. I think, especially if delivered in the future virtually again, this class may benefit from being split into 3 50-minute sections, as I think students would be able to engage and focus on the material a bit more. I did enjoy Professor Spiegel trying to make this lecture as close as possible in format to what it would be like in person. I do think that the virtual discussion sections could have been tailored a bit more to the needs of students, such as going over common mistakes or things to remember in the practice of organic chemistry.
The recorded lectures were very convenient, given the ability to speed up or slow down the lectures as necessary.
This class suffered a little from being on zoom. I could tell the course would have been more engaging in person, but on zoom the class could sometimes feel a little unengaging and detached.
Better zoom/ technology use
small group TA sessions were helpful, the only issue was that there were a lot of technical difficulties during lecture the first few weeks
Early morning exams were difficult for those in later time zones
Lectures were good, and Spiegels mid-class breaks to discuss hobbies were a fun way to make the course more personal.

I found that section and lecture were often not very engaging over zoom, not much use of the chat or raise hand function happened. I would have appreciated study halls with the TAs to go over material as well as additional review sessions.
The course was not well-adapted for the pandemic. The instructors essentially acted as if everything was normal and especially did not take appropriate measures to adapt exams for online learning.

The way the files and notes were uploaded to canvas can definitely be improved because some notes were consistently not available to all students and others were uploaded late and hard to find in the disorganized file section of canvas. Recording the lectures and uploading them to canvas succeeded.
Sections were helpful, but the engagement during lecture was rather low.
Recorded lectures should always be used

There needs to be set proctoring from the first exam onwards, in breakout rooms, as other classes have done in during this past semester, and every student should be required to sign an honor pledge on each individual exam. Test questions should emphasize application over knowledge so as to level the playing field.
What succeeded was the discussion sections, but they could have been longer.
The discussion sections were effective but the lectures could have been more organized.
Syllabus that was more clear and followed the courses progression accurately
Lectures were recorded. Not much to improve on. However, lectures were not particularly engaging (but is organic chemistry ever?)
COVID-19 lectures made the teachers and TAs feel very out of touch with their students. Most/if not all material was learned independently.
Feels like the PT's, TA's, and Prof Spiegel forsook us right before finals.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Only if you are committed to the workload and interested in the difficult course material.

only those who are very confident in chemistry ability. this course has many students who are very strong in chemistry and will break curves against your favor, and for most students who place out of gen chem, i'd strongly consider taking chem 220/221 (the standard sophomore sequence which is also available to first-years who place out of gen chem) instead of the 174/175 sequence

It depends on the student's interests and major. If someone wants to take the time to dive deeper into chemistry, this is a great course for that. It isn't too challenging conceptually but does require time to master the subjects.

If its required for your major, take it. If you really liked CHEM 174, take it. If youre pre-med, do not take it (and thats only because more and more schools are not requiring a second semester of organic chemistry).
Only if the course is a requirement.

YES, take this course!! Of course, only take this course if you are genuinely interested or excited by organic chemistry because it is a lot of work/time. But, if you are interested, you should definitely take this class. You will actually learn to think about organic chemistry in a way that is super fascinating. As long as Prof Spiegel is still teaching it, this will NOT be a boring memorization class. It is a class where you will actually learn about major topics in organic chemistry and apply them to different situations. Amazing course.
Yes if you need it to fulfill your requirements, grading is not too harsh.

If you're taking this course, it's either for a requirement or you're just that genuinely interested in chemistry. I can't say I particularly liked organic chemistry (but not many people do), but I would say it's a good class and I would recommend it.

I would not recommend taking this course unless you have to for major/grad school requirements. The regular organic chemistry class (not first-year orgo) would be a much better decision. Half of the students in this class already took organic chemistry in high school and it is impossible to compete with them.

No. While organic chemistry is necessary for pre-med and some majors, I would recommend not taking this course unless you have a very strong background in chemistry, felt like Organic Chemistry I was a breeze, and are interested/somewhat knowledgeable about biochemistry. Otherwise, I think it would be beneficial to take Chem 221. Often, as someone who is not very familiar with biochemistry but did very well in Organic Chemistry I, I felt like some of the examples in class were over my head and often confused me more. It was a challenge, and accessing resources for help in this class is kind of difficult. I did not think that the class was taught with the most clarity and organization. The class is very fast-paced. The exams tended to be, in my opinion, very difficult and stressful, and often drew on "chemical intuition" which I feel like I did not develop. Problem sets were manageable, and I think helpful in actually learning the reactions discussed in class. In my experience, this class was less straightforward than other science courses. If you do choose to take it, absolutely take the corresponding lab, as I think that lab definitely helped in enriching the Organic Chemistry II curriculum taught in this class.

I'd recommend it if you have a serious interest in organic chemistry, as you do learn a lot of it. That being said, for someone used to STEM courses having clear right answers and full explanations behind what is going on, the subject matter can be a bit infuriating.
I would recommend this class only if the student is extremely interested in ochem, is willing to put in a lot of work, and is able to self-study well.

I would recommend this course if you need it for your major. It's very different that CHEM174, but Professor Spiegel is very nice and wants you to succeed. The content is challenging, but the course is designed to help you through that because it's curved, there are recommended practice problems for every concept, and there's lots of opportunities to ask questions or clear up misunderstandings.
I guess, you would have to take orgo 2 in most cases anyways. The pharmacology knowledge you get is pretty interesting.

If you are excited to learn about molecules and their behavior in reactions, then yes, I would say go for this course. You learn a lot about why and how certain reactions work. However, if you aren't as invested in these topics and you don't need it for your major, then just keep in mind this isn't a course you can take and expect an easy grade; you will have to work hard to understand what is going on in these reactions and try to apply these concepts to a lot of situations that you may not have seen a similar example before in class on the exams.

Only if you have to take it for your major or pre-med or you really like organic chemistry. Can be very frustrating at times and easy to feel like you are the only one struggling (which is definitely not true!!).
I would recommend this course to a student if they were pre-med, a chem major, or enjoyed learning about chemistry.
No.
If you have to take it then yeah
If your major requires it or you are pursuing pre-med track - yes. Otherwise, no - it is more trouble than it's worth.
Yes, organic chemistry is a very interesting subject.
YES. If you are taking Orgo 1, SEE IT THROUGH. You cannot claim to have an understanding of "organic chemistry" unless you have taken orgo 2. But be prepared to work hard before exams.
I would, I really enjoyed organic chemistry and this class was very engaging and the subject matter was interesting.

Yes if you have both the time and passion for the material. You will learn a lot simply because you will spend almost every waking moment on this class and its material. However, if you enjoy learning about molecules and how they react and would like to immerse yourself into it, go right into it!
I recommend the course only if you have to take it.
Yes, I really enjoyed it. It's definitely a lot of hard work, but the content is super interesting, and it's rewarding once you understand the concepts.
I would recommend this class to students who are prepared to have their understanding be principally self-driven.

I would recommend this class to any student who took the first semester of orgo. Despite it being significantly less organized with Spiegel, the class is really not that unreasonable. Also, the class was curved pretty well so grading should not be too much of a worry.
It is an important class for many fields but challenging.

I definitely would not recommend this course to another student. The course wasn't taught in the best way possible and could be so much more better in terms of how bad the test situations were handled, how short, unhelpful, and confusing at times the feedback given on exams and psets were, and how the material was taught in general.

I would recommend this class to chemistry and chemistry-related majors, but not necessarily humanities or soft science-oriented premeds who might be motivated to take this class. This class goes fast, and the students are very diligent.

Yes, this course is awesome, you learn so much and Professor Spiegel is so considerate and generous. The only thing that can be improved is not to backload so much. There were so many reactions that were thrown at us that we could not possibly in a short stretch. Hurry over alkenes and Diels-Alder which we already learned most of and then take time on examples of the named reactions later, especially seeing additions/condensations in synthesis problems. David Spiegel is awesome

I would recommend this class to a student in a non-pandemic year. The class is well taught by Professor Spiegel but did suffer under the virtual format. Professor Spiegel makes the material engaging and is good at teaching all of the mechanisms required, but there was a lack of consistency and scrutiny when grading. The class had no proctoring or honor pledge until the final exam, and on some of the early exams some students did not even have their camera on. Sometimes, I felt that the grading was quite random, as some TA's would take off massive amounts of points for trivial errors, while others would barely take off points. A more equitable grading rubric would make the grading distribution more fair.
If you are pre med and need to take this class for your pre-reqs or major, yes.
I would recommend this course to students who need to take it for pre-med or major requirements.
Only if it is necessary for your major or track. Otherwise, it's a huge time-sucker learning information that can't be applied to other contexts
I would only recommend taking this course if it is necessary for your major due to its high level of intensity.
No.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments:
live virtual lecture
virtual discussion section
recorded lecture w/ live virtual section
Recorded lecture and in-person lecture
Virtual discussion section
Live virtual lectures were recorded. Virtual discussion section once a week.
Live virtual lecture and virtual discussion section
Lectures were held live, but recorded, and the course had an accompanying discussion section.
